Award.AwardTitle: The Fate of Molybdenum and Its Isotopes in Deep Marine, Oxide-Rich Sediments: Implications for the Mo Isotope Paleoproxy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Molybdenum (Mo) isotopes have the potential to act as tracers of past ocean anoxia. However, to validate the application of Mo as a proxy, a better understanding of the diagenetic processes affecting its isotopic composition in deep marine sediments is necessary. This research will examine the coupled cycling of Mo and manganese with sulfur, carbon, and iron in sediments underlying deep oxic waters, the effect of which on Mo isotope composition (and thus its validity as a proxy) is currently unknown. Major and trace elements in a set of modern sediment samples and associated pore waters will be analyzed to investigate potential Mo sinks, diagenetic pathways, and mechanisms for release into the overlying seawater.

The outcome of this work will have important implications for the reliability of Mo as a tool for understanding past ocean conditions. Funding will support a female beginning investigator at the University of California- Riverside. A German doctoral student from the Alfred Wegner Institute will join the project for two months, strengthening international collaborative ties. Two undergraduates from UCR will also be trained. Results will be shared with industry collaborators in Uruguay through a series of lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The concentration and isotopic composition of molybdenum (Mo) in seawater can be sensitive indicators of the oxygen balance of the global ocean through time, which has a direct impact on life. Such balance has particular relevance for past and future ocean-scale oxygen deficiency, which is exacerbated during times of ocean warming. Under the assumption that strong preferential uptake and long-term burial of isotopically light Mo beneath oxic waters increases the isotopic composition of seawater, those increases should point quantitatively in the geologic past to the extent of oxic versus anoxic seafloor, where widespread anoxic conditions are also associated with petroleum resources and economic accumulation of metal deposits.  


However, extensive recent work has explored Mo mainly at the highly reducing sulfidic end of its biogeochemical cycle; therefore, the main goal of this proposed project was to explore the fate of Mo, including its isotopic composition, in sediments deposited under oxic water column conditions to improve our understanding of the Mo isotope as a paleoproxy for the water-column oxygen state. More specifically, this study focused on the coupled cycling of carbon, sulfur, manganese, iron, and Mo in oxide-rich, organic-poor modern marine sediments in both surface and deep subsurface layers. The goal of this research was to answer fundamental questions regarding Mo cycling in oxic environments, such as 1) the influence of global-scale deep subsurface cycling of Mo on its isotopic signature in the seawater, 2) the ultimate fate of Mo in sediments without a sulfide sink, and 3) the fate of Mo exposed to diagenetic alteration in deeply buried sediments. 
To answer the above research questions, an extensive sample set, collected during R/V Meteor expedition M78 off Argentina and Uruguay, was analyzed (>150 samples). The investigated sediments are characterized by rapid deposition, leading to a persistence of abundant reactive iron and manganese oxide phases below a narrow sulfidic zone in concurrence with low amounts of reworked organic matter. Analysis of carbon, sulfur, iron and manganese contents, as well as determinations of sulfur and Mo isotope signatures, indicate that in these iron-dominated sediments, non-steady state sulfur cycling is recorded in the various sulfur phases present. Iron and manganese alteration and associated release of Mo under limited sulfidic conditions strongly influence sub-surface Mo cycling, potentially leading to the formation of Mo-rich layers in the deeper sediments and/or a release of Mo into the water column at the sediment surface. Because the concentration and isotope signature of Mo are among the primary proxies used to track the ocean oxygen state through time, our results suggest that those approaches could be compromised by short-term recycling of Mn-Fe-bound Mo in sulfide limited environments. 


The funded project supported the work of several undergraduate students in the lab. The students were trained in all applied chemical procedures and introduced to various instrument techniques – thus providing hands-on experience. Furthermore, the early career scientist had her first experience as PI; all necessary analytical training and mentoring of the students was carried out by the PI. Additionally, an exchange graduate student from Germany was introduced to and trained in research-related analytical methods by the PI. Several publications resulted from this research, and the findings were successfully presented at national scientific conferences and invited talks at several institutes by the PIs.
